Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Unified Three-Dimensional Dynamic Modeling for Drilling and Milling Tool Assemblies (STaRC-3D)

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this collaborative research project is to derive and integrate (1) the spectral-Tchebychev technique for modeling drill/endmill dynamics, including the actual fluted geometry, and holders; and (2) the extended receptance coupling substructure analysis technique, for joining tool-holder dynamics to spindle-machine dynamics. The approach to meet this objective includes four primary tasks. First, unified models for three-dimensional dynamics (coupled torsional/axial and bending) of milling and drilling tools, with actual cross-sectional geometry and twist, and holders will be derived using the spectral-Tchebychev technique. Second, the receptance coupling substructure analysis method will be extended to enable the prediction of three-dimensional torsional, axial, and non-axisymmetric bending dynamics. Third, the tool-holder dynamics will be coupled to the spindle-machine dynamics. Fourth, the integrated approach will be verified experimentally.

If successful, this work will advance the drilling/milling modeling community by making available a new analytical framework for predicting the coupled torsional/axial and non-axisymmetric bending dynamics of drilling/milling tool-holder-spindle-machine assemblies in an accurate and numerically efficient fashion. This capability does not currently exist and is necessary when modal testing is inconvenient (measurement of many tools in production environments) or impossible (torsional measurements of twist drill-holder-spindle-machine responses or micro-scale tool dynamics). Knowledge of the assembly dynamics will enable a priori selection of optimized operating parameters, which will have immediate application to the aerospace industry (a Boeing 747 airplane has 1.3 million drilled holes) and the US economy (126,000 US companies use 2 milling machine tools and employ 1 million machinists, programmers, and related personnel).

Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHARLOTTE, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this proposal was to derive and integrate: 1) the spectral-Tchebychev technique for modeling drill/endmill dynamics, including the actual fluted geometry, and holders; and 2) the extended receptance coupling substructure analysis (RCSA) technique, for joining the modeled tool-holder dynamics to the measured spindle-machine dynamics. The approach to meet this objective included four primary tasks. First, unified models for three-dimensional dynamics (coupled torsional/axial and bending) of milling and drilling tools, with the actual cross-sectional geometry and twist, and holders were derived using the three-dimensional spectral-Tchebychev technique. Second, the RCSA method was extended to enable the prediction of three-dimensional dynamics. Third, the modeled tool-holder dynamics were coupled to the measured spindle-machine dynamics. Fourth, the integrated approach was verified experimentally.

Intellectual merit: This work advanced the drilling/milling modeling community by providing a new analytical framework for predicting the dynamics of drilling/milling tool-holder-spindle-machine assemblies in an accurate and numerically efficient fashion. This capability is necessary when dynamics testing is inconvenient (e.g., the measurement of many tools in production environments) or impossible (e.g., torsional measurements of twist drill-holder-spindle-machine responses and micro-scale tools). More broadly, the work advanced dynamic modeling of three-dimensional structures in general.

Broader impacts: Knowledge of the assembly dynamics enables pre-process selection of optimized operating parameters, which impacts the manufacturing industry and, by extension, the US economy. Four graduate students and several undergraduate students were involved in both theoretical and experimental portions of the research, thereby positively impacting the future workforce in manufacturing. The findings from this work have been presented in international conferences and published in peer-reviewed journals to realize broad dissemination.


Last Modified: 09/09/2013
Modified by: Tony L Schmitz

The approach to meet this objective included four primary tasks. First, unified models for three-dimensional dynamics (coupled torsional/axial and bending) of milling and drilling tools, with the actual cross-sectional geometry and twist, and holders were derived using the three-dimensional spectral-Tchebychev technique. Second, the RCSA method was extended to enable the prediction of three-dimensional dynamics. Third, the modeled tool-holder dynamics were coupled to the measured spindle-machine dynamics. Fourth, the integrated approach was verified experimentally. Intellectual merit: This work advanced the drilling/milling modeling community by providing a new analytical framework for predicting the dynamics of drilling/milling tool-holder-spindle-machine assemblies in an accurate and numerically efficient fashion. This capability is necessary when dynamics testing is inconvenient (e.g., the measurement of many tools in production environments) or impossible (e.g., torsional measurements of twist drill-holder-spindle-machine responses and micro-scale tools). More broadly, the work advanced dynamic modeling of three-dimensional structures in general. Broader impacts: Knowledge of the assembly dynamics enables pre-process selection of optimized operating parameters, which impacts the manufacturing industry and, by extension, the US economy. Four graduate students and several undergraduate students were involved in both theoretical and experimental portions of the research, thereby positively impacting the future workforce in manufacturing. The findings from this work have been presented in international conferences and published in peer-reviewed journals to realize broad dissemination.
